description: Structured rubric for evaluating whether a research work or paper constitutes a potential invention under MPEP §2106 Step 1 and Step 2A criteria. Designed for use in LLM-based triage or contextual reasoning frameworks.

facets.name: Nature of the Described Innovation
questions: What kind of thing is being presented — a method or process, system or apparatus, manufactured product or tool, or composition or material?
What specific features, functions, or relationships in the research description indicate this classification?
Which part of the paper’s approach or design demonstrates how it operates or what it is made of?
Why does the described work fit best as a method, system, product, or composition?

scoring.0: No identifiable inventive element; only discusses ideas or correlations without describing a process, system, product, or material.
scoring.1: Vague or implied; mentions a 'framework', 'approach', or 'model' but does not clearly define what it is or how it operates.
scoring.2: Clearly defined; explicitly states the invention type and explains what it is or how it runs (method, system, product, or composition). A direct quote can identify its type.

facets.name: Conceptual Foundation or Possible Judicial Exception
questions: Does the paper’s main contribution rely primarily on a conceptual principle, mathematical model, natural law, or natural phenomenon rather than a concrete technical implementation?
Which aspects of the described work show focus on an underlying idea or correlation instead of a fully engineered mechanism or process?

Could the same concept, relationship, or behavior be carried out on generic commercial hardware and standard software without introducing any new computational mechanism, architecture, or specialized system?

scoring.0: Pure idea, theory, or correlation; no defined mechanism or architecture.
scoring.1: Partial mechanism; some algorithmic steps, schematic, or pseudo-process, but incomplete or not reproducible.
scoring.2: Fully specified mechanism; reproducible steps, system architecture, or design that someone skilled in the art could implement.

facets.name: Practical Application or Technical Integration
questions: What specific mechanisms, interactions, or operations transform the conceptual idea into a real-world implementation or effect?
How does the computer, device, experimental setup, or material perform the described method or process?
What physical, computational, or technical operation is being improved, optimized, or newly enabled?

scoring.0: No measurable technical output or test; results are qualitative, speculative, or unverified.
scoring.1: Includes quantitative data or metrics but without a clear baseline, benchmark, or comparison to prior work.
scoring.2: Shows a measurable improvement or performance change relative to a defined baseline or standard, supported by numeric or objective evidence.

total_score_interpretation.interpretation: Primarily theoretical or conceptual; lacks concrete mechanism or measurable effect.
Partially developed; some mechanism or data present but incomplete or unclear.
total_score_interpretation.next_step: Request clarification or missing details from authors.

total_score_interpretation.interpretation: Technically implemented with measurable performance; likely meets invention-level criteria.
total_score_interpretation.next_step: Prepare draft disclosure and initiate prior-art search.

rules: If A = 0 (no identifiable inventive element), classify as Scientific Discovery immediately; no further scoring needed.
If B = 0 (no concrete mechanism or architecture), classify as Scientific Discovery immediately; no further scoring needed.
Use evidence primarily from Methods, Design, and Results sections — avoid relying on Abstracts or Introductions.

metadata.context: Invention identification framework for AI/technical papers
